reviews.review: Cat -poo-cino definitely worth the effort. Like most people it was included on a tour, but with just us and the driver it was a gentle pace and relaxing. The gardens contain a lot of local fruit, herbs and spices, so it was good to see them all growing together to get an appreciation of what the plants looked like. At the end of the tour you are given a taster of various teas and coffees, free. There was no pressure to buy anything at any stage. However, my husband is a keen coffee drinker and was keen to try to luwak coffee, so bought a cup. He was very impressed, I had a quick taste and it was a well rounded taste - however even here buying direct it was expensive. Definitely worth the trip. We saw the 3 civets in the cage, but my understanding was they were just there to show you what a civet looked like, and more were wandering around - although I might be wrong?They didn't seem stressed in any event.
Must see for caffeine lovers :). It was fantastic to see this. Great place for tea and coffee lovers.You can also buy special bali coffee and tea here.
Luwak Coffee. Love the free coffee testing and the info of all sorts of coffee. Purchase the coffee whichever you like.

We ended up buying 10 boxes. We actually ended up going here twice. The first time was through our driver that we hired to take us around for the duration of our stay. This was one of his recommendations. The 2nd time was on our river rafting excursion and that was a little more formal. Our first visit wasn't really much of a tour since we didn't sign up for one. But our driver basically set us up to see how the coffee was made and then to a taste testing session.*warning* this may be obvious, but they give you about 16 different cups of coffee/tea...just take sips! We actually finished all 16 because they were SO good, but on the drive home had a bit of a stomach ache lol. They also let us try this apple type tobacco which was pretty good too, but it is very strong and unfiltered so be aware of that.As far as all the teas and coffees, I mean we ended up buying 10 boxes to go so that goes to show that they were VERY tasty and the lady sold us on how each benefits you health wise (whether it be true or not). And yes, we did try the Luwak coffee (cat poo coffee) and it wasn't really that bad. Just the idea probably will turn people away. But we did it to just say we tried it. There are other plantations around Bali so I'm not sure if there is a difference or not but I would recommend taking an hour to drop by one and trying all their flavors!

Coffee plantation was interesting but the luwak Cat is like a slave !. I wouldn t go there again as those poor animals in a very small cage are showing mental problems due to there bad life kept in a cage. If you feel nothing looking at that / you have no heart and respect for life .. The staff was friendly the place is nice.they could still do there business without those animals there..

Great little stop-off except for one thing... This a beautiful plantation with nice gardens to wander around and see the different tropical fruits as they are grown. The place has a very generous business model in which you can try the teas and coffees for free and choose if you want to buy. Unfortunately this is all spoiled by the presence of caged civets. These are the animals used to produce the Luwak (cat-poo) coffee. The cruelty issues associated with keeping these predominately solitary, nocturnal animals in battery cage conditions is well documented. The demand for the gimmicky coffee only encourages the continuation of these horrible practices. If I had done my research before I would have stayed away. If you do choose to visit, by all means enjoy the teas and coffees but please say no to a cup of Luwak.

Nice coffee & tea. Our guide was very informative.We did a taste tester of all the different coffee & tea they offer. My favs we're the Luwak coffee & Lemon tea.There are assorted animals & birds through out the plantation aswell,which is pretty cool.You can take pictures with one of the baby Luwaks for a fee.At the end of the tour you can buy coffee & tea from the store.I'd recommend this place if your a coffee or tea lover.

Cat-poo-chino :O) you have to try this coffee lol. Well worth the stop and visit :O) ...... you are given free samples of all the teas and coffees they have to offer and it is a small cost to try the special Lewak coffee ...... Cat-poo-chino lol Lots to see ...unusual things/plants to see ....interesting. Good shop where items of interest `T` shirts / Rice Wine / large selection of tea`s coffee`s etc are not too expensive to purchase/take home gifts :O)

Showcase for coffee. Attentive service and guiding around this plantation, which shows different plants, and gives you free samples of various concoctions from coffee, and chocolate to more herbal things and mixtures. Expectation that you might purchase so the driver can make a commission.

Coffee not good and really expensive. This is one of those tours where you feel like you are forced to buys inferior products due to the free tour and nice staff. Tour was educational but coffee was so horrible and though well I do like one of the teas. Equal to $10 USD for a portion of less than 10 teas.

Unexpected visit. Our driver pointed out the coffee plantation when we were driving through Ubud. We popped in and were quickly whisked through a small pathway with a guide. Our guide pointed out and explained the different coffee plants and tea leaves. You are given free samples of all the teas and coffees they have to offer and it is a small cost to try the special Lewak coffee. We were lucky enough to hold a Lewak and get a photo with it. Overall was an enjoyable visit and is worth the small cost to try the Lewak coffee.

Must Visit in Bali. Driver recommended this Coffee Plantation and it was incredible. The whole family enjoyed it even the six year old. The tray of teas and coffees were delicious, my favourites were coconut coffee, vanilla coffee and mangosteen tea.

Poo coffee, surprisingly good. For the moment we arrived we were so very well taken care of. Our host was simply delightful. This is a fun and educational activity and we learnt quite a bit.The tasting tray of teas and coffees is excellent and there is absolutely no pressure to purchase anything.The vanilla coffee and lemon tea were winners with us but the real surprise was the poo coffee - it was really good.The chocolate samples were enough to send us off to the shop to make a few purchases but at no stage did anyone pressure us to buy anything. This is a really interesting stop on the day trip to Ubud and we enjoyed it very much.

A coffee garden in the green. For those who wanna see the process of making Luwak coffee and this day sleeping animal - Luwak ( Only active and hunt for their food at night ) This is the right place to go. Although I didn't find the Luwak coffee to be as good as what I was expected but they do offer other selection of unique coffee variant to try on for free. Plus a beautiful padi field view, I believe this place can offer a moment of stamina restore after a tired adventures from other tourist spot.

Delicious, fun and educational. As we were nearby at the Holy Springs, my local tour guide suggested we stop by the coffee plantation and it was amazing! I got a tour of the forest where they grow many different types of beans and plants. I even got to roast some coffee beans over the fire. The smell and feel of the warm beans was magnificent. After the tour, I got samples of delicious and natural teas and coffees. I chose to purchase a cup of the lewak coffee--which was delicious. Naturally, I bought some coffee and the best dark chocolate to bring back to NYC. Such a great experience!
Great!. You get a free tour and free coffee and tea to try which is great! Poor animals in cages though which you clearly see don't have enough space to walk around ..

Interesting and beautiful. The plantations visitor area is set on a hillside overlooking beautiful views of the jungle. A guide shows you how the Luwak coffee is traditionally produced by demonstrating the shelling, grinding and filtering process, and you get to meet a couple of Luwaks although as they're nocturnal I don't think they appreciated being woken up by a poke in the backside on a rainy afternoon. From here you're taken to a tasting area where a selection of teas and coffees are offered to you to try,as is a cup of Luwak coffee but this isn't free but is is IDR 50,000. From there you go on to the shop where several products are offered to you including the very highly price Luwak coffee that personally I don't think is worth the price for its taste, but the cost isn't unreasonable as its entire production is done by hand and is very intensive. This is only a short visit but was a very interesting and worthwhile one.

Informative guide and great birws. This is a must see in Ubud - an informative guide takes you round the plantation and, at the end, you and your party get a number of free samples to drink overlooking the most beautiful of views. Definitely try the Luwak coffee!

Interesting and educational with good free samples. It was interesting to hear all about the processing of the coffee especially that of the Luwok. Once we had samples we went to the shop where we were followed around by the server (clearly commissioned based) and didn't look that happy when I didn't want to buy anything but pay for the coffee we had. If I could give it 3.5 rating I would, it wasn't average but it wasn't very good either.

Educational and fascinating with good samples. What an amazing experience! This was the highlight of our day trip. So many things to see here, not just coffee! Ginseng, cinnamon, pineapples, giant passion fruit, ginger, turmeric, papaw, lemon grass, coco plants, and a variety of tea. You can see the cats that poo the coffee, surprisingly they were asleep despite all the coffee! The coffee her was fantastic and we bought a cup each and enjoyed the view once our tour was over. Highly recommended!

Not worthy . They give u 3 variety of coffee and 6 variety of tea for tasting and will explain u the benefits of all the tea variety for the special coffee they charge 50000rp(if u want to taste).its like a small nursery where they have a kept some trees. 5000rp for parking
Great tea's and coffee !. Very relaxing, no pressure to purchase anything, the tea tasting was great, the coffee was good, the surrounding forrest was beautiful, bathrooms not so...

Luwok Coffee. This was amazing I am not a coffee drinker and I was made into a believer with the Luwok Coffee. I bought one kilo of it and I intend to buy much more. Also I bought the turmeric tea which I love and will be ordering more of in the future.
Interesting visit. I enjoyed wandering around the place and learning about the coffees here. The coffee sampling is worth sampling and I also purchased some coffee to bring home.
Over rated. Not very scenic , felt like you were herded to the different areas so they can sell u overpriced coffee.

Come here only if you really want to buy coffee or tea. The coffee was delicious you get to sample about 9 cups. After you taste all the samples you can walk around the coffee plantation not much to see. I did like that the sales people weren't pushy at all. I would only recommend this place if you are going to purchase tea or coffee if you're not doing waste your time...go to the beach instead.

Delicious coffee!. Entry to this place is free so it is definitely worth the visit. You get free samples of coffee and at the end you can buy as much as you want. You also learn about their methods and the animals used to make the coffee.Highly recommend!

suprisingly informative. firstly I suggest going with a guide, as this was only made into a great visit because our driver came with us to explain everything as we walked through, otherwise it would have been a walk ended by some coffee. So, as you walk through your guide will explain all the plants that you see which was pretty amazing - cocoa plants, papaya, lemon grass, coffee plants, passion fruit, pineapple, vanilla etc. then we were greeted by a cute little lady that showed us how the coffee beans were roasted and ground, she then took us up to try over 10 I think, free samples of coffee and tea, overlooking an amazing view. The whole experience was amazing
Loved it. you get to taste many varieties of coffee and tea free of cost, brought home coffee and tea and perfumes and essential oils

Great spot very educating. As a person who has been to Bali many many times i still look out for scams and tourist traps, lucky this is not one, just a short tour through garden with informative guide about coffee ,then you get to try teas and coffee's, ,all they ask is for you to look and maybe but from there shop on way out which we did,a bit costly but very good produce soworth it....enjoy its great fun

Interesting tour. It was interesting to visit the plantation because the guide takes you through the various processes needed to make coffee, plus they show you the various plants grown at the plantation. Free taste of teas, coffee, hot chocolate and tobacco are offered - you need to pay a bit for the Luwak coffee though (I say it's worth it!). There's a shop with a lot of offerings to choose from - tea, coffee, spices, chocolate,natural beauty products, essential oils..

Excellent, informative coffee plantation tour. Well-planned tour, allowing many interactions at various stages of the coffee production process. Included is a tray with many different types of tea and coffee to taste. You have to pay extra for the Luwak ("catpoochino") coffee, but it is a price worth paying.

Looks good, tastes better. Great little tour of the coffee roasting process and how each mix is flavoured. Ideal for a nice sunny day and coffee tastes great too! Wonderful tour guide Olid explained each flavour and gave us our first taste of the well known Luwak coffee!

Informative & delicious. Great opportunity to see how the teas & coffee are grown, processed & cooked. Yummy chocolate & delicious teas family made & served with a shy smile. Thoroughly enjoyed our sampling & brought lots of stuff home for us to enjoy when our holiday came to an end. Worth the effort!

Just got to taste the tea/coffee, no explanation!. We visited here on a day trip. It was a nice place, you got given a tray of testers which could be shared between the two of us. However was just a marketing ploy to buy the tea/coffee afterwards. Our waitress sat with us and played with our little baby (which was lovely!) however it was just so that she could earn her commission. It cost 50000K to have a coffee that the beans are of the animal... We dont drink coffee so was a bit of a waste. Maybe if you are an avid coffee fan you may enjoy this

If you are not a fan of coffee, it is not the place for you. They don't really tell much of information how they make coffee and tea. Just showed some part of the place, told us some small info, the animals slept already, tried some coffee and tea. Got some back home but tea was not that good not like at the place...wish there were more stuff to see like can get close to coffee and tea planting area and more details about it

It's OK. I am a big coffee drinker. I had read good reviews from both trip advisor and a couple of tours books, so I requested our private driver to make a stop at Satri. I did walk through the plantation and sat with my family to enjoy free samples and IDR50K worth of Luwak Coffee, I bought some teas and coffee afterwards. There are so many coffee stops and plantations throughout island, I had checked a couple of others. I did not quite understand why Satri? The coffee is ok, just like the other two places, Other Ginger/Herbal coffee or teas samples are on the average side. The view of plantations is nice, but with too many tourists. I would recommend you make a stop if it’s on your way, not worth a detour.

Amazing (And I hate Coffee). When my partner and I stayed in Bali last year we went white water rafting. Our driver took us to this coffee plantation on the way there. Before going there though my partner and I didn't really want to, it was a long drive and neither of us really drink coffee.When we got there we had a tour and then a free tasting of all the coffee and tea they had. There was about 10 and they were all amazing. We couldn't believe how fantastic it was. Coconut coffee was our favorite whilst mangosteen and ginger were among the best. We didn't have any money on us while we were there, we were devastated because we couldn't buy anything, but our amazing driver told us he would buy it for us and we could pay him back when we got to our hotel, so we took him up on the offer. Unfortunately my partner lost the coffee on our last day in Bali at the beachwalk shopping centre, for some reason she took it with her and it was never to be enjoyed or seen again.I'm still mad at her to this day for it, its half of the reason why we are going back to Bali in September, can't wait to go back!I recommended the plantation to a friend at work and he loved it as much as we did. The coconut coffee was his favorite also.
Gourmet coffee tasting. Very friendly and informative guide explained all my questions. Tasted several different coffees and bought coffee and tea.

Nice tasting and grounds. Our guide stopped here. Though a bit commercialized there are many nice fruit trees and coffee and other plants to see. Then the nice tasting. Many different flavors that we're all pretty tasty. Prices seemed fairly high but comes with the territory. Worth a stop.

amazing !. In the middle of all the hustle bustle is this tranquil place. Free entry , staff so informative and the tea's are so delicious ! loved the red ginger and mangosteen. try and walk out without buying some ... haha , trust me you wont !!
No probs bringing it back to aus either as its processed .
"Catpoocinno" haha

A beautiful place. I love this place! It's so beautiful and amazing. The people are so nice and the coffee/tea tasting on the end is awesome. The trip takes about 30 minutes. Everything is free except the luwak coffee and the souvenir shop. The only think I didn't like was that the souvenir shop was very expensive.

Worlds most expensive coffee taste test! Hmmm didn't taste like poop!. I was asked by my personal tour guide if I liked coffee. Of course I do! So he took me here. BEAUTIFUL plantation sights and then the poo of the Lewark coffee was introduced. I tried it. It wasn't bad but the thought had me kinda grossed out. I recommend going here! great experience!

Sample City. Fun stop while touring around. Learned about how coffee is grown and roasted. Had a great time tasting all the free coffee and tea samples. Ended up buying a bunch of varieties to bring home, including some perfume for our daughter.

Well set out coffee experience!. This place does not look like much from the front but once inside you are given a tour of the coffee making process and you are able to sample all sorts of teas and coffees in a spectacular setting overlooking the jungle. For coffee lovers I recommend trying and Lewak coffee as it is fantastic!
Coffee anyone?. Excellent visit learning about different coffees, very interesting grounds, good shop, brilliant staff who took time to explain. Glad I went. Thank you.
Great place to stop and try this unusual coffee. Great place to try various coffees and actually see the Civat or Mongeese that create this unique coffee. Put some mossie spray on 1st though.

Great coffee experience close to Ubud centre. Located near Ubud this small enterprise offers an insight into their larger plantation. Get to see the luwaks (or civet) and get to sample the teas and coffees. Free entry but they do have a little shop where you can purchase.

Wasn't expecting this to be do interesting. We went to the plantation as part of a day tour. I'm not a big coffee drinker and wasn't expecting much from the visit. What a pleasant surprise. It was great to see how all sorts of plants grow naturally. As well as coffee we saw vanilla, pineapple, pepper, ginger to name a few.We were offered 9 tea and coffees to try and given the option to buy, but with no hard sell.Well worth a visit.

One of the best experiences in Bali. I was really impressed about the Coffee Plantation. It is indeed a must see attraction. There I could see how coffee, cocoa, tangerine trees really look like, also I could see the animal that "makes" coffee (Luwak), pineapple plant, cinnamon tree, vanilla plant and so many other exciting plants. They offer free tasting drinks(I recommend the herbal tea and lemongrass tea), and for 50k Rp you could have a taste of the Luwak coffee(it is very strong coffee). Also they have a shop where you could buy coffee and tea souvenirs and a bunch of other great stuff.The staff is very friendly and polite and very good English speakers, explaining you all of the processes for making coffee and growing the other plants. There is no entrance/visitation fee.

Worth The Visit. Whether you are a coffee drinker or not you will enjoy this stop. You pull into the parking lot and immediately begin walking down a path with a variety of coffee plants. Our driver pointed out the different varieties but there are guides available who work here. You walk past a couple of the cats that make the famous Luwak coffee. Then you will see a demonstration of how the coffee beans from plant to coffee. Afterwards, a guide will escort you to the tasting table where you will be given a sample of 12 items - 4 coffee, 4 teas and 4 hot chocolates. You will be given the option of tasting the Luwak coffee for 5 dollars....we shared 1cup. It tasted slightly less bitter than regular coffee. Then, you have the opportunity to go shopping at their building where you can purchase all the items you tasted plus a variety of spices. Note these items are expensive but we has a lot of fun & love buying things like this as souvenirs. I definitely picked up some saffron that I thought was a bargain at 6 dollars for 1/2 oz consisting the cost in the States.....and 1/2 an oz goes a long way. All in all this was a worthwhile visit that I would do again.

Intersting place. Was guided by a local guide thru how the signature Luwak was produce. Seen many other types of assorted fruits plants/trees instead. Towards the end of the trip, was been brought to a rest stop to an open-air pavilion where they serve you their various beverage menu for try out.Very educational trip!

Absolutely loved this place. Our driver suggested that we come to the coffee plantation during our day trip and as neither of us like coffee we thought it would be a bit of a waste of time. However I was so wrong! It turned out to be one of the highlights of the trips! Our guide spoke fantastic English and she pointed out the coffee beans on the plants, the pineapple plants, aloe Vera, lemon grass etc growing out in the fields. We were showed the coffee beans in their natural form and then when they were roasted. I even tried my hand at roasting the beans and pounding them into ground coffee. We tried 15 teas and coffees and all were nice and some were amazing. The coffee does not taste like the usual coffee served back home so we loved it. There is a huge shop where you can buy the tea and coffee as well as some lovely gifts. Yes the shop is a little expensive but you don't pay for the tour and it was very educational. If you like food and learning how it grows and is processed by hand then this is the tour for you.

Really interesting experience. Much more than just coffee!. We really enjoyed this, but we had a great guide which really helped. He talked us through the whole range of different fruits and plants, breaking off leaves so that we could smell them. We saw other guides just walking straight garden to the coffee and tea area. The tasting is free although here's an obvious expectation that you buy something which we were fine with considering the time and way we'd been looked after as well as the wonderful slection of free teas and coffees. Love place overall and a welcome stop on the tour. Not too sure about how well the animals are looked after as there were three of the civets in small cages which we didn't care for. I'd like to think they let them out to forage for the coffee but either way it's not something I can condone.

Very nice!. This was a brief coffee stop during our day tour. We were shown around the plantation by a nice employee who taught us how the coffee was made and especially about their special luwak coffee. It was interesting to learn and at the end we were given free samples of their teas and coffees to try along with some banana chips. I don't really like hot drinks but tried a few and must say that their vanilla coffee is divine! My partner tried all of the samples and paid a little to have a cup of the luwak coffee which he said tastes rather fruity. Overall, it was a very nice visit and we are planning on returning before leaving Bali, to buy some coffee to take home with us.
Nice tea. Was a nice visit learning about the coffee process, the tea was nice and refreshing with an enjoyable atmosphere and scenery

Beautiful and fascinating tour. If you enjoy seeing where tropical fruits and veggies grow, this is a good tour for you. We saw citronella, lemongrass, cacao, papaya and banana trees among others. Also the famous Luwal (cat poo) coffee was fun to learn about. You can sample a set of their herbal teas and coffees for free. PS - do not buy fragrance items from their gift shop because they are way overpriced and you can just get similar items from Ubud Art Market.

Try a Little of Each!. A wonderful little location for seeing coffee beans on the tree, vanilla vines and even papayas. Learn how the coffee beans are processed and then relax while they set you up with coffee and tea samples. Explanations are given and you are able to enjoy the views as you sip away. Shop for yourself or friends as they have tea, coffee and spices on hand!

Interesting. An interesting guided tour to see the various spice and coffee plants. However, like many of the plantation tours, the tour is quick and you are led to the coffee tasting with a fantastic view and then to the spice shop. Interesting if you have never done it before.

Not my best port of call on my visit to Bali. Rather commercialised and canned type offering. Also quite pricey if I remember correctly. I love Kope Luwak and but every time I visit but the presentation here and the caged civits di not impress me. Sorry to say.

Wonderful guide. knowledgeable. We had a wonderful young man as our guide through the plantation. There where many tasty samples of different teas and coffees which you could try for free with an explanation of each one. You did have to pay $5 aus for the Luwak coffee but I felt this was well worth it after you hear how the coffee is made.Well worth a visit.
Coffee Lovers Paradise. For those who love coffee this is a must visit on your way to Ubud...do not forget to taste the Cat Poo coffee...!!

Coffee and Chocolate!. Visited the coffee plantation during a bike ride. We parked up and wandered through a well set out garden full of cacao trees, mangosteen trees, coffee trees. Very peaceful. Our guide gave us a run down on each of the trees and how they are used. We saw a little palm civet, the cute little animal that part digests coffee beans which are then used to make (I think) the most expensive coffee in the world. These little animals are caged for a month and then set free. We tried a selection of coffees and teas and I really recommend the coconut coffee which is delicious. I bought a packet plus some dark orange chocolate which is so very good. The Balinese at the plantation are charming and engaging. I really can recommend a visit here.

Must Go. This place falls on the way to udad temple if i remember the name correctly. It was not in our itinerary but our cab driver stopped here and told its a nice place u should go there. He was right we really liked the place not due to animal or art but due to the overall feeling. And the variety of coffee was amazing they give you small shots of coffee free of charge so that u can decide which one you want to order. Few of them were so nice that we ended up even buying the packets of coffee. Overall a nice break in between the journey.

Quick Kopi Pitstop. We stopped here with our cycling tour...nice little walk through their plantation (cute jungle/rainforrest) The Coffees & teas are definitely worth a try, while enjoying the views. We also bought some of their Chilli Chocolate...which had a gr8 afterburn. Worth a quick stop!
Plantation. Was recommended by our driver. We found it peaceful and a great experience. Yes, you can buy their products, but you don't need to. You will enjoy it.

Wonderful spot to stop . We loved this place. An amazing view and area to get some great pictures. You get to try out a selection of coffees and teas. I don't even like tea and I walked out buying some it was so good. If you want to try the kopi Luwak coffee it is 50,000 rupees per cup. Souvenirs costs between 100,000 rupees to around 250,000 but they do accept common forms of credit cards in the gift shop as well. The staff is also super friendly and knowledgable. Bring your camera and enjoy your time. I highly recommend this stop along the way.
Interesting. This was a great insight into how coffee is made, we had a great tour person who was very knowledgeable. The free coffee tasting at the end is a nice touch too
Kuwak coffee and great teas. A nice roadside stop for delicious tea, a small tour and my first taste of Kuwak coffee. Friendly staff. Pricey for the coffee but a great gift.

Interesting place. A very interesting place to try coffee and tea at, the staff were very friendly and welcoming. they had nice flavored coffee, i really liked the Balinese ginger coffee and the mangostine tea. I took some back as a souvenir and now I'm really sad that they are almost over. :(

great teas & coffees to sample. something different to do while on holidays, this was a great experience, so many different beverages to sample, i was not sure about going here but truly enjoyed it - give it a go !!!!!!

Interesting place to visit.. Interesting to see the different spices and coffee growing and how it is harvested. The little animal in the cage didn't look too flash. The tasting was very much enjoyed by our tour group. The Coffee Luwak was the best tasting coffee I have had. The different teas were also well worth trying.The prices for tea etc ok little on the expensive side but they are allowed through Aust customs which is a bonus.

Tea and coffee are amazing , but poor animals . People who work there are extremely friendly . They laugh with you . Talk to you . Treat you in a nice way.First they took us in a tour to show us plants there and coffee bean trees.And other spices trees.Then they show us the animal it self that eats coffee beans and then poop them " it called Asian Palm civet " looks like a wild cat .The coffee comes from this animal called Luwak coffee and it's extremely expensive .There are different kind of tea there and some taste great and some taste just ok . Few kind of coffee and some taste good some not . They make you taste around 12 kind of coffee and tea for free but to get a cup of Luwak it costed us 50000 rupiah . And they show you how to make coffee from zero to the cup.Poor animals were sleep at this time because they wake up at night and eat coffee bean . Workers there claimed that this animal eat the good beans and refuse to eat the bad ones . And they actually don't force it to eat beans " I doubt it " as they love it eat it anyway. The rest of the day they feed them banana and pineapple . Anyway it was a good experience but I home they were honest about being good to the animals and if they can just release it from the cage .Ps. They have a small market and they sell all kind of coffee , tea , massage oil , perfume and chocolate . But it's not the cheapest choice .

Taste, taste taste. we had possibility to get to the plantation and taste several coffee and tea from fruits we have never heard of... It was amazing, especially get to know background info about them and their healing effects. Nice experience, we have bought some as a souvenir and for private use.

Keep away. This is a horrible tourist trap that most driver's just stops at even if you do not wanna go..totaly vaste of time and money.The worst thing about this place is that they keep the animals in small metal cages that are out on display all day and theze are nocturnal creatures that get stressed by this life.You will be given a pretty story if you ask but it is all a lie when they say that the animals is just staying there for a short time...it is not true and theses animals sufferers a lot and are just feed coffee beans so they can make expensive coffee beans in an industrial way a not as is should be done by collecting the beans from the wild animals in the nature.This place should be removed from this list and make a 180 and walk fast away.Not recomended and will never ever go back.

Little gem. Surprisingly good. Had a guide to take us through the spice plantation and then an extensive tasting plate of different tea and coffees. You had to purchase the cat. Poo coffee for about $5 but worth it to try. They have a lovely gift shop with realy food stuff. Try the organic chocolate. No pressure sales.

Try everything and be prepared to buy everything too!. So many different flavors of teas, coffees, and of course the world famous lombok coffee that is native to Bali. Definitely get the sample platter and try everything, you'd be surprised how much you'll enjoy each one. Our taxi driver suggested that we stop here on the way to our hotel and we thought he was just trying to hustle us so we were a bit apprehensive at first but this ended up being one of the highlights of Ubud. This is a MUST taste! lol

Nice visit. Worth a stop on the way to somewhere else. We went on a tour and it was in-between temples. I couldnt get over that Ludwig coffee where the little creature eats the coffee bean then poos it out then the woman washes it all off then roasts the coffee and gives you a taste (I wouldn't try it) but apparently it is a luxury item. Not for me - I really liked their assorted teas though.

Free taste of teas and coffee. as you walk into the Tasting are you pass but countless varieties of fruits and spices. They serve samples of 4 coffees and 7 teas which can be purchased in their shop. Great experience.

Favourite stop on our day-long tour of Ubud. We ventured around Ubud on tour of about 6 different landmarks, this was probably my favourite stop. You didn't have to pay entry fee and we got a fantastic tour guide who explained everything at their plantation and answered all our questions. Was absolutely fascinated by everything they grow there, from Durian to pineapple, to ginger, tumeric, peppercorns and lemongrass. The coffee and tea tasting was fantastic, we were suckers and ended up buying a fair bit of stuff, but have brought it all home and everyone that has tasted it has enjoyed the product as much as we have!

Coffee Lovers Will Enjoy It!. A peaceful place and you will be greeted by a staff who will teach you how to value good coffee. I love the vanilla coffee very much. The coffee body scrub sold here is quite cheap as well.

Pouring tropical rain but still had a blast. the herbal teas and coffee tasting was great tried the famous cat poo cino too.excellent!
The staff were brilliant well able to explain the process from plant to cup as done one onsite, we thought the chocolate was delicious but a bit overpriced.
Worth a visit if you love coffee

enjoyable. tasting, knwing every single detail in the coffee plantation world was a bliss for us. However we bought many tea bags and coffee. it was kind of expensive though. We tasted the luwak coffee known as the golden coffee! A new experience

Nice view, however coffee and essential oils from the gift shop are poor quality. It's good for a short break;Lovely view;People who work there are nice and speak very good english;The coffee was instant quality. As a regular coffee drinker I was disappointed. The Luwak coffee was not that good either. I perceived it more acidic that the "Bali Coffee" , even if locals describe it the other way around. I had doubts about what goes into the coffee and tea that they sell. There are no ingredients listed on any of the packaging. The employees were able to describe the processing of the products in detail,insisting on the bio qulaity. I ended bought a few souvenirs, including two tiny bottles of essential oils. Two months later after arriving back in Europe I checked the recipients .  The top of the recipients is sealed by a rubber/plastic foil which has a powerful chemical smell. So much so that it almost neutralizes the scent of the content.  The consistency is as fluid as water.I threw everything out and decided to not to gift any souvenirs.

Tourist trap. Expensive shop with fake tee.. Local drivers get their share to take you there. On the way from the airport to Ubud our driver asked us if we wanted to stop somewhere on the way, for coffee. We said no as we were tired. After some time the driver said he needs a break and will have a coffee if we do not mind and took us to this place. The guy talked interestingly about plants they have and civets but he also said some things that are hard to believe, for example that they keep the animals in cages only for one week, then they catch another one from plantation and they replace it with the one in the cage. Then they give you some teas and coffee to taste which are nice but very very sweet. This part is also nice. Then there is a shop where you can buy low quality tees for exorbitant prices.

A gorgeous view, coffee tasting, but I wouldn't buy anything there. My guide took us here and it was certainly a beautiful place. We sat down and they brought us a whole number of coffees and teas to taste - free of charge! So that was nice. However when I inquired about purchasing I was shocked at the prices. About 15$ for a small bag of coffee!!! I want to support local farmers and markets but that was exorbitant. I'm happy there but I wouldn't consider this a must do.

Interesting but not essential. Visited the Satri Coffee Plantation as part of a tour. It was interesting looking around the site, learning about how the different coffee flavours are produced as well as tasting. We did actually buy some Balenese coffee but my impression is that it was a pleasant experience but not really a "must see"

Great Place. This was a great place to go to on a rainy day and check out how certain coffee beans are made! They have an amazing staff who guiding us around telling us about the process of the coffee and how it all came together. At the end you get a sample of coffee and tea and then you are able to buy bigger cups and sip on them overlooking a beautiful view. They also have a shop at the end where you can purchase the coffee and tea! They make great presents for friends and family back home! I loved the Bali coffee and lemon tea the best!

Coffee tasting is delicious and interesting. Fun experience but feel very badly for the civets. I'm sure they could give them much better living conditions, especially for the high priced coffee they provide the owners.
Waste of time. A tourist trap. I recommend you remove it from the itenerary. I am not sure what is the point of having this. This coffee is not even drun in Bali.

Pleasant & Genuine Experience. A short walk down their path, surrounded by coffee and cocoa, leads to a woman heating and grinding coffee beans.. they explain whats going on, the stages, then move onto the tasting table a few minutes walk away... they prepared 12 different drinks.. about 8 coffees, 1 hot chocolate and a few teas and we tried them - some interesting combo's.. then we went to their shop.. Given that it was all free, I was happy to buy a small bottle of their massage oil. Whilst it was slightly overpriced, the fact that the rest of it was free, and the girl explaining things was a genuine girl trying hard (and clearly from a poor background), I was happy to do so (and tip her).. Personally enjoyed this short visit

Not for people who really know coffee. The coffee plantation is nice, full of different plants, pretty good for children maybe. But we were hoping to find some good coffee, but the coffee they have is really low quality, with lots of artificial flavoured coffee. We were pretty disappointed.

informative. nice informative walk through the gardens. explanation about the tropical plants like coffee plant and so on... coffee and tea testing with of course possibly to buy afterwards. bit expensive but still acceptable as small souvenir for friends.

Must Do. went there from elephant ride and after being shown different plants and being offered to dry and then pulp the coffee beans they take you to there little shop and make you a tray of 12 different drinks, (free) to try and purchase if you wish. Webtried them all and then purchased some from the shop to bring home, all the processes are the same as traditional no mods to make it, even an old lady roasting the beans over a wood fired stove, short tour but is a must

Coffee made from poo!. Loved it! Didn't know what to expect but was good to learn something different , it's all free.... The hosts are lovely ... Never laughed so much in a long time! Wasn't going to drink it then though I'll never do this again why not? I enjoyed the coffee..

Mixed feelings. Whilst it was interesting to learn about kopi luwak, the coffee was not out of the ordinary in taste and doesn't justify the cruel conditions under which the animals live. (Would there be any justification?) In spite of the touristy spele, the animals are not allowed to roam free nor do they live in clean enclosures. Being able to taste test the range of teas and coffees was fun.
coffee farm. ok not what I expected not very big,most of the time is spent tasting different teas and coffee, and to buy coffee there a bit pricey

Tourist trap but enjoyable testing. Quick walk into fake plantation and then you can try all their thes and coffees. We enjoyed the testing (20 glasses for free). Their Luwak coffee at 50000IDR is not very good and too expensive. If you are french or italian do not try it, it looks like a bad instant coffee, you will be disappointed. Product in the shop are super expensive, but if you need to bring back some gifts they are fine for it.
Great. The tour is nice and quick to show you how the coffee is made. The staff makes you feel comfortable and is very kind. Great experience.

Interesting & staff are informative. I'm not a coffee drinker but really enjoyed this little tour. Our guide was very well spoken when it comes to english. Was interesting seeing the Luwak and hearing about how the coffee is made.We did purchase a bag of the vanilla latte coffee powder which unfortunately didn't taste anything like what he'd made us at the coffee tasting :(

Beautiful outing - to see spices growing in nature, coffee tasting. Loved our somewhat unplanned visit here. You get to see and experience the smells of many natural spices and herbs by walking through the jungle plantation. You then have the opportunity to see how coffee grows and is made the Balinese way. There is no official tour (our driver came with us), and the visit itself is free. At the end, you are rewarded with an array of 20 different coffees and teas to taste, which will blow your tastebuds away.Of course, there is probably an expectation that you will buy some of the coffees/teas in the shop, though we found these to be great gifts for people back home (much higher prices than average in Bali - but it is for tourists, no?). Make a stop here. Really something fun and natural to enjoy.

Yum. You are shown briefly around the plantation, then whisked away to tastings ( my favourite part)' delicious , try the Luwack coffee most expensive in the world..then off to their shop to buy your favourites.

Tourist trap. The welcome coffee and tea was interesting. Difference preference for everyone, but you should be able to find something you like. I particularly loved the coconut coffee. Just try and take a look at the shops, just leave if not interested. It was a stopover from my day tour, I wouldn't particularly come all the way for this.

Trying Bali Coffee was nice. It was interesting trying all the Bali coffee's and teas they had to offer. I really enjoyed the vanilla coffee, ginger tea, lemon tea, and coconut coffee. The normal Bali coffee was a bit bitter and the hot chocolate was not 'milk' chocolate. I went to a couple of the different coffee places as well (part of different tours you can do in Bali) and they all had the same things. Always worth a try when they give it to you for free as part of the tour! Enjoy!

Taste the legendary Kopi Luwak.. The famous Luwak coffee is certainly something to cross of the list when in Ubud. Along with a beautiful selection of teas and other coffee flavours given to you on a plate to taste, you can learn more about the famous 'cat poo coffee' and purchase some from the gift shop at a fraction of the price that it sells for in the UK.

mini tour of coffee planation. Basically ended up a self guided tour because the guide gave very little comments other than the basic information of the site. More could have been said about the types of flora and fauna in Ubud Bali. Although it was interesting I thought it was very commercialized with the emphasis on selling their products. I did buy some special coffee to bring home to family but was disappointed with the products especially for the price they were charging. I would probably not go back there again.

Nice little stop over . Staff are lovely and its interesting to have a look round and the free samples of tea and coffee are both tasty and unusual. But unsurprisingly the whole thing is geared towards selling some tea or coffee to you in the gift shop at the end, which is pretty expensive and them some

Tourist trap. They offer samples which are interesting but is just a tourist trap they give you a 10 minute tour and then a tasting but it's all about the volumes they can get through with selected trip operators and when you go to the shop lol buy elsewhere don't pay 10 times the price

Drink your Luwak coffee here. Coffee lovers hear about the famous Civit Cat coffee, called here Luwak. It is reputedly the most expensive and superlative tasting in the world. A walk through the gardens to the terrace overlooking the incredible visits of the plantations allows one to choose to taste the coffee for about the price of a Starbucks in the US. My taste buds failed to rise to the challenge of finding the coffee ethereal. But it was fun to see the smelly civit cat and try the legendary coffee. The setting is spectacular.

Coffee Plantation,more like local fruit garden tour!. Hoping to get experience of a real coffee plantation tour. Stopped by Satri Agrowisata on way to Titra Empul Holy Springs. The walk through the garden was pleasant with each local fruit tree represented. If you have not seen durian, cocoa, coffee, soursop, jackfruit, mangosteen, you can see it here all in one place. The coffee part was disappointing. They set up a demo station to show how coffee bean was roasted by pan frying and then pounded and sieve to get the fine granules. After which you proceed to coffee tasting (this was complimentary unless you want to taste the Luwak Coffee at IDR 50,000. All the samplers have honey and was very sweet so hard to tell their true flavor. They do have tobacco grass you can roll up to smoke (n/c) - great if you are a smoker! After sampling they direct you to the gift shop where the products are sold. No pushy sale here (thank goodness) but everything higher price Han shops/supermarket in Ubud. We bought some gift items as felt bad for the girl who was assigned to be our guide for the tour and tasting as believe if you don't buy she does not earn commission. We paid with CapOne visa and they were going to charge us 3% credit card charge and we told them our visa company does not charge the 3%. They did take it off - so be aware here. Pleasant visit but no true coffee plantation tour.

Great variety of Products! You can even see the infamous Luwak Cat!. Great drinks and farming products! Their Kopi Luwak (coffee) is good! I know I'm not an expert in coffee but the flavor really tastes different! Their products for drinks are very good, nice flavor and good price. Recommended if you stay in Ubud! Ask your local guide to take you here.

Coffee Plantation. We travelled by taxi to the plantation, it was very nice to see how all the coffee is produced and cocoa as well, and many more variety of plants. After your walk through the plantation there is a coffee shop and you get to drink the traditional Balinese coffee. Also to buy souvenirs. Not too bad but once is enough.

very expensive useless coffee. i lovd everything in bali apart from this stupid coffee we bought.. the place was nice scenic view of the place was amazing ... but i feel cheated because i bought this coffee which was suppose to be organic high quality stuff but which actually is third grade quality coffee after preparing its leaves behind a black residue... seems like the coffee is adulterated ... i would recommend everyone to visit the place but never buy anything from these hyped tourist places

Clever Use of the Family Land. The family land has been planted for three purposes, grow and sell coffee, show the tree/bush/herb plants of the region, and make money. It is satisfies its ecotourism billing if you have a guide to point out the plants and their uses. The civets that help produce the special coffee are caged to view. Tastings to suit your interests are offered as a preliminary to enticing you to buy in the shop. Coffee, tea and various fruit and herbal teas are available.

Great Service. We stopped in for a look around and were surprised at how much fun we had! The young man who greeted us was very knowledgeable and the tea/coffee tasting was amazing! Recommend to stop by as is a great experience! We purchased a few teas and some coffee but is worth the extra $..
Worth a look - great views!. Brief but interesting trip. Fantastic view from the terraces. Felt a little sorry for the cats however. Worth a look in though.

I learned a lot about coffee and spices in Bali. Very organised and staff are trained well in Engish. I learned a great amount of how coffee is made here and why it tastes so good. Nice to have the free samples of all the teas and coffee available to buy in the gift shop.
Interesting. We enjoyed our visit and tasting all the different varieties. The guide was very informative and you can buy your favorites in the shop to take home.

Interesting. The staff was great and the coffee and tea was good! interesting tour and great fun to get to taste everything!The shop was very expensive however but did have large variety of items, great for gifts!

fun tour. our tour guide was extremely happy and cute and loved explaining the poo-coffee..she was so sweet...she then let us taste test 10 coffees and teas...all amazing..def worth the trip (free) and bought some coffee...tried the Kopi Lukaw (poop) for $4/cup...a days pay for our tour guide

The cofee taste is so so.. The view is so good.
The taisting drink of jacooneko coffee is very expencive.
Free tasting drink is poor.

Interesting. Very informative with extra friendly guides & staff.
Coffee expensive to buy in the factory shop.
Do buy vanilla essence to bring home-the best I've ever used.
Nice Stop. We were able to sample some nice beverages and made a few purchases. They had a nice demonstration on how they make their products

Great tour, super country drive. The drive to Satri is fabtastic. It's one straight road outside Ubud and the road is simy jammed packed with artisan boutique cultural shops. The road seems to stretch for miles and the shops are endless. I dyou are looking to buy any sculptures or artwork this is a haven. All the wares are presented beautifully outside the hop doorways. When you arrive at Sati, everyone is very professional and friendly. YOu go on a tour which is not extraordinary but certainly capture the key essence of coffee growing. At the end of your tour, you are seated at a table to sample several different beverages.You can spend all day with the samples if you like, There is no pressure and you are encouraged to relax with the beautiful mountain views. After your tasting, the exit path takes you through the souvenir store. I knew that I wanted to buy sone treats, but there is absolutely o pressure to buy anything at all.All in all it's a really nice day or half-day trip out. It's nice place to go as a group, but I was alone and felt really relaxed and recharged. I didn't stay very long because I had a driver that I was paying for the day and we had to start our journey back.

Fascinating tour of coffee plantation where they produce Kopi Luwak coffee.. Tremendous tour. We saw numerous types of plants and fruits throughout the plantation, and were able to taste test a dozen of their most popular coffees. They also produce the Kopi Luwak coffee which was made famous by the movie, "The Bucket List." There is a very good demonstration of how the coffee is processed by natives, a time-consuming process to say the least. Very friendly folks.

Ok. A tour guide explains the different types of coffees they make and give you several samples to try , some are very tastie some not so good , but at less you can try before you buy .Only one problem I had with this was the little Asian Palm civets locked In a cage to make the Luwak coffee ... Let them out please !
Relax for a minute. We found this an interesting stop. Some of the coffee testers I didn't enjoy but loved others and purchased.

Interesting to see.... It is interesting to see, but if you are coffee lovers, you will not really enjoy it.Some of the coffee drink offered for free are instant quality, The coffee what you can buy are over price compare to similar in Ubud and packed in plastic bags.There is nice nature around, chance to see coffee plantation.

Horrid tourist experience. We were taken here by our driver after we wanted to stop for a coffee. This isn't the place for a nice cup of coffee but more a tourist pastime. We were taken at a very very slow walk around the "plantation" by a bored girl who recited her lines at regular intervals. The coffee tasting was small and mean and we couldn't wait to get outta there! Save your time and money
Beautiful drinks and pleasant staff.. Luwak coffee and amazing teas served here. The grounds are also pleasant. Pricey gift shop though.Loved it.

Unique Bali coffee experience - "Cat Poo Cino" :-). We came across this gem by chance. It offers free entry and a free tour of the plantation is provided, where guests can see coffee beans, cocoa beans, spices and fruits all growing naturally - including many that we had no idea how they looked in the natural form. We also saw coffee beans being hand roasted. After the tour, guests are invited to taste a selection of 7 hot beverages, and another 6 on request, all for free. Think Bali coffee, vanilla coffee, sweet potato coffee and spiced hot chocolate. Guests ate also invited to try Luwak coffee - a bean eaten by a cat like animal, digested and then extracted from the animals waste - hence cat poo cino! Definitely a strong unusual brew, costing 50,000 rp, around $5 which is pretty expensive by Bali standards, but worth it for the unique experience!

Drink everything except Kopi Luwak. This place is a relaxing place where they sell home grown tea creations and coffee to tourists and locals. It is a great place for purchasing a gift for someone. The tea tastes nice when you are there but when I got them home, it tastes a little different. The prices are a little steep here.

Torturing animals!. Do not drink or buy coffee Luwak! The civet cats are kept in cages and made eat only coffee beans, which shortens their lifespan significantly! Also, they are nocturnal creatures, but to entertain the tourists, they keep them awake in the day time...Their unnatural diet (mainly coffee cherries) causes a lot of health problems and leads to premature death. Time to wake up people!!!!

Coffee delight. This is a free attraction. You can just walk in visit the forest and get a delicious plateau of different coffee's and tea's to try. If you want to bring some home, there's a nice little spice/coffee shop.You can also check out the Lowak's, too cute!

TASTE OF LUWAK COFFEE. Had a great tour, they offer samples of all their coffee & tea. It was an experience to see them roasting the coffee beans. Be prepared to buy their products after sampling the drinks.

Interesting place, good tea and coffee. . We went there as part of a tour around bali and fortunately our driver had a lot of knowledge about the plants and the place in general. Maybe it's a bit unfair to rate it 4/5 as the 4th point is actually to his credit. But anyhow, it's a beautiful place and they give you a lot of free tasters of their products. You're not obliged to buy anything afterwards, but it's hard not to as their different teas and coffee are really good. There was a girl there telling us some stuff about the process and the products which I found quite interesting. She did seem as if she was a bit tired of telling the same things over and over though. Then again, she was pregnant so maybe she had an off day. All in all, a nice place for a quick visit and some tasty beverages. The cat poo chino is good but a little pricey (50k idr).
Satri Coffee and spice. Was there this week, had a great tour, they offer samples of all their coffee, so delicious, of course you end up buying which is good, highly recommended. Beautiful setting/.
not worth it. the products are overpriced, they are just ordinary and the same as the one u find in street vendors. We were visiting it only because this place was included in our tour.

Nice experience, Coffee just so so. Good experience to see how they roast the bean. Dislike seeing cat were kept in cage and fed with beans. Coffee are not natural as they were so sweet and artificial.

WORST TRIP EVER. BASED ON ANIMAL ABUSE.. Don't bother going. Animals are caged and used for their poop to give us 100 dollar coffee that is rather boring in taste! They harass you into purchasing products that are CRAZY IN PRICE!
Good place for coffee/tea additct. I really love coffee, hence it really fit me. I enjoyed Luwak coffee very much, it costs okay for me to try it. It really tasted good.

Not worth to visit. Was there in December and only a few coffee plants. They explained to you how the luwak coffee came from. There you will get to taste different types of coffee. However, if you want to try the luwak coffee, you need to pay IDR 50,000 for a small cup. The place is fill with mosquitoes and I felt not worth a visit.

Great Experience!. Another great experience in Bali- the coffee plantation tour! Since I used to be a coffee addict, now a tea lover.. this place was really fit to me. when I walked through the pathway leaded by the local guide, my mood turns into better seeing different kind of plants, trees and spices particular for main coffee ingredients. then, our guide lead us to the processing area and showed us the demo. after showing us everything including animals, there was a free testing of coffee with different kind of flavors like Luwak, Gensing, Cocoa, Vanilla and etc. They have a shop for their products if you want to buy coffee, tea, spices and other souvenirs. We had a great time in this place. Also, there is an orange plantation on the other side of the road.

Very interesting tour. We really enjoyed our afternoon at the coffee plantation. Very informative and such a peaceful environment. Enjoyed a Luwak coffee and purchased more to take home with me. The little animals are very sweet

Leeway coffee. No Lweewak for me. They show you how the animals are feed the coffee beans and how they extricate and roast the at the other end. Very new venue; gardens are immature. And 30% sugar is added to the tasting menu consisting of flavored yes and coffee gratis. There is a gorgeous view over looking the plantation house.

Interesting garden tour, processing demo and coffee tasting. This wonderful "green" plantation specializes in traditional-style coffee growing and production. First you visit their civet zoo where these little guys help produce their Luwak "poo" coffee. They digest the outer husk of the bean and excrete it. Then workers wash the leavings, winnow the inner husk away, hand roast it over a wood fire, pound it into fine granules using a large wooden mortar and pestle, then sift it and re-pound it. Then they bring you attractively presented complimentary tastings of regular coffee, vanilla coffee, cocoa coffee, cocoa, lemon tea, ginseng tea, and more. A taste of the Luwak coffee costs about $3-not my favorite coffee. They grow all the herbal teas and cocoa on the plantation. Their tasting area overlooks a lovely, breezy rice terrace and pool. Definitely worth a visit.
Interesting experience. It is definitely an interesting experience, all the new tastes and flavored experienced at the source. Not too much development from that point, might evolve in the future...

The tea was great. On arriving were rushed very quickly through the grounds. Our guide was not interested in having us look at anything, Three minutes into the tour of the lovely surrounds, one of the woman proceeded to chop the head off a chicken in front of the kids. It was off putting and took away from the tranquil surrounds.I drink a lot of coffee and did not enjoy this coffee. The tea was great, but as others have commented when you are ushered into the shop, it is just sugar powder and not tea at all.

A Lovely Surprise!. When we booked a taxi for a tour around the Ubud region this was not on the agenda. However further to a conversation on my love of coffee our driver Wyan suggested we call in. What a great surprise with a lovely tour followed by tea and coffee tasting - all free!

Best coffee and great scenery. Our tour guide thought we would like to experience this place and thank goodness he did. It was interesting to see how they make coffee and chocolate and the animals that help in the process. Their coffee is amazing and you get to try testers at a nice location up high overlooking plantation. Great to visit

Catpoochino delicious. On your tour around Bali it is likely that you will be brought to one of the Coffee plantations - your driver will receive commissions for any purchases that his clients make. You are not obliged on are you pressured into purchasing although this trip includes a coffee tasting experience. I thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience and consider it a must do if you are in Bali - Satria staff were excellent and fun and made our visit fun. the coffee and other products on sale are expensive but at least you know where they are from - the coffee in the markets is approx. 1/3 the price.

lovely experience. Had a great tour by one of the lovely guides, & then tasted the teas & coffees which was fantastic. Tried the lovely Luwak coffee & it was like a Japanese tea ceremony with the coffee being brewed in amazing individual pots - great experience & lovely clean setting - loved it

Great tour with explanations and samples. When we arrived we were the first there, the young man took us around the property explaining the process of coffee making and then we got to sample many types of tea and coffee - iut was a fantastic experience that was really enjoyable - even dared to try the Luwak coffee!
Best Coffee Ever. The tour was very interesting and you won't believe how good the coffee is. We had a very peaceful afternoon looking out over the rice fields with the best coffee in the world...
Great tea and coffee tasting. Staff are friendly and you are taken to your own table with loads of tea and coffee to taste and a bonus at the was awesome Bali chocolate.

Nice place to visit , but they sell you different coffee. It was a nice place to visit and the coffee and tea were delicious at the plantation. We purchased several bags of the pre made coffee and when we got home it tasted nothing like what we had. In particular the flavored coffee. We very disappointed to say the least

Nice but Quick and Overpriced . Our tour guide was lovely and funny :) she took some nice pictures of myself and my partner overlooking the panoramic views.The tour was very quick and sadly not lot of plants on the plantation were in season at the time so we didn't see much. We saw the Luwaks which were really cute, it was a shame to see them in such a tiny cage which is why I gave this an average rating.We stopped for tea and coffee sampling which was nice, good selection of 10 or so samples.If you are expecting good, strong coffee like back home then I would recommend against this place as most of the testers are tea and you only get a couple of small cups of weak coffee to try.The whole idea of this place is to sell merchandise which is very over priced. We felt a bit obligated to purchase something. We grabbed a bodyscrub which we could have gotten in town at half the price.Overall good but not what we expected.

The 8 cups of various flavoured coffee didn't taste good. It took less than 10 minutes to finish touring the small plantation area with four caged "musang". Luwak Coffee was served at IDR50,000 per cup whilst they served us another 8 cups of coffee in various flavour free of charge. Luwak Coffee tasted alright but not the others.

Very nice and casual activity. This activity can be completely free if you choose which is always nice! You get to have a nice walk through the gardens with all the local fruits and flowers. Then they show you and allow you to participate if you wish in the traditional process of making the coffee. 12 different tasters of coffee and tea are complimentary as a welcome drink. If you want you can then purchase something from the gift shop, or you can pay about $5 US to try the Luwak coffee.Lovely afternoon and you can spend as little or as much time and money as you wish. The staff is friendly and it's beautiful scenery.The only reason I did not give 5 stars is because the luwaks were kept in very small cages and put on display. They are nocturnal animals so should be sleeping during the day. I did not like seeing their natural way of life disturbed, and, although I understand they are important in the process for the Luwak coffee and am not against that, I wish I could have at least seen them in a nicer more natural environment.

Coffee coffee. An interesting place to halt on way to Mt Batur. One get to see the different types of coffee with a very hospitable staff. Enjoy different flavors of tea and coffee and visit the place. A short halt of 30 minutes a very refreshing.

Probably great coffee, if you can ignore the luwak´s caged up.... The place is great and worth a visit.., but with beautifull stressed luwak´s caged up with no water, it is hard to sit and enjoy your coffee.
We gave all the animals Water and they drank like crazy.
It is devastating to see how we treat our animals for our own pleasure...

Worth a visit. Stopped here as part of day private tour. Really enjoyed the tour and seeing the different plants and coffee beans and learning about the lowak coffee. Our guide was friendly and informative. Tasting the coffees and teas on terrace enjoying a wonderful view ended the tour wonderfully.

Nothing like learning about Lowak coffee. I thoroughly enjoyed my walk through the plantation and tasting the different coffee flavors. I ended up buying coffee, chocolate and spices. Saw the Lowak animal and learned how they processed the coffee
Don't buy anything from them!. Spent a bit of money buying the tea only to come home and fine that it's just a bag of sugar! And the leukat coffee is just ordinary coffee so dnt buy into it trust me

What a wonderful surprise.. We had a morning to spare so decided to do some last minute shopping. We asked our driver where we could get some coffee and to our surprise we ended up with so much more. The tour was informative and really pleasant. Then we participated in the tea and coffee tasting. Yum yum. It was all so delicious and the staff wonderfully friendly.

Great tour and great Views. Really interesting the tour guides English is excellent and gave us a lot of information as we walked through the plantation. the view as you sample all the different types of coffee is amazing and the Luwak is interesting to sample

Great views while trying different coffees. We really loved our stop here. It's nice to walk through and see all the different things being grown and then to sit and sample the coffee and tea while overlooking the terraces is nothing short of amazing.

Definitely a great stop on our trip. I was so excited that all the coffee was organic, and made in Bali. I also never thought a coffee from poop of a cat would be good, but was great coffee. If you like coffee or tea, and like to know about native plants, a fun way to spend 30-45 minutes.
coffee. great place to visit lovely staff they will take you around and you can sample the different types of coffee also see how the coffee is roasted

Horray for Coffee and Tea Lovers!. I really enjoyed visiting this coffee plantation. We tasted different varieties of coffee and teas. We love their vanilla coffee and the mangoesteen and lemon grass tea. The staff were so nice and very accommodating. They showed to us the trees/plants of the some coffee. I find this trip an interesting and very informative . We also bought some coffee and tea to bring home. Unlike other places we visited in Bali, this place has no entrance/admission fee. You just go there and try their coffee and teas and it's up to you if you want to buy some to take home.

Hidden Gem. This place was fab. The people who showed us round were so helpful, kind and interesting. They all spoke great English and I loved that it is a family run business. Great little shop at the end with some lovely bits to take home. Loved it and would highly recommend this.
Amazing Coffee. Enjoyed my visit here and tasted many flavours of coffee, also had a shop so I just had to bring some home
ok for a quick stop. stopped there for a quick stop . the coffee and teas are expensive , they do you show you the different kind of trees that grow variety of fruit and spices .
Nice. Stoppoed off on the way back to Umalas and was a lovely distraction. Nice samples and got some tea to take home. Had a picture with the owl as wel try the poo coffee

Spice Garden walk. Wanders through the spice garden identifying the various plants from which we get our beverages. Coffee beans, cocoa pods, vanilla beans, aloe Vera plants, pineapples and spices. There was a tasting session followed by a visit to their shop for purchasing personal supplies.

So wrong. Rare coffee,exclusive,bull.This coffee after passing through the digestive tract of a Luwak was at one point painstakingly collected by gathers in their natural environment.Great.Now visit to see these animals caged,feed all sorts of coffee beans to digest and the outcome is collected from the cage.You can see these animals are stressed,it's daytime,they(some)stalk up and down their cage,they naturally should be asleep and out in the trees not stuck in a tiny cage.Exptoitation,simple.
Great coffee and teas!. I don't drink coffee and really enjoyed this place. It was delicious! It had different teas to enjoy in addition to the coffee.
same same. in ubud area is maybe 50 eco farm plantation,or more.I taste kopiluwak in 3 diferent farmsand have same taste,but the prices are more expensive if you compare to supermarket in ubud.

Informative visit. Amazing and extremely informative. You will be freed a taste of 12 teas and coffees, including the famous Luwak coffee, which has beans coming through a civet intestine. We watch the process for how they make the coffee - all laboriously hand done, as are most things here.
Poop coffee. Try specialty civet coffee, made from the poop of civets. Must like real strong, bitter coffee. Add lots of sugar. Other coffee is offered for tasting.

Must visit!. A really beautiful plantation with very friendly guides that tell you about the plantations which they have such as coffee, cocoa, vanilla etc and the highlight is the luwak coffee (catpoochino). It is very interesting that they show you the process that the coffee goes through and I even got to roast and grind the beans! Tasting the selection of teas and coffee was also a highlight!
Loved it. Great tour of the plantation and lovely to try all the different coffees. Felt a bit sorry for the caged Luwak cats :(
Worth a vsit. Very cool experience...great food and coffee...we loved it. They offered a great variety of coffees and se sat overlooking the plantation, great views
Great Coffee and Tea. Awesome coffee collection and plantation. We loved it so much that we bought a lot to take with us..
Coffee and Tea: a must visit. Wonderful learning and tasting experience. The surroundings are charming, and the teas (not just the coffee) delicious!

Taste amazing tea and the famous Luwak coffee!!. Very interesting! You'll find a big plantation in the balenese jungle where you'll learn many things about fruit trees, tea and, of course, coffee! People present you how the special "Luwak coffee" is made! At the end, it is degustation time! You'll be able to taste a dozen of different flavored tea and coffee. It is very delightful! You could also spend50 000 RPS for a Luwak coffee - a must do for coffee addicts in Bali!

Great place. Oir driver stopped here and we were very impressed. Beautiful scenary and he pointed out ginger, pineapples, lemongrass etc in the gardens. We learnt about the coffee process and the Civets/Luwaks. Then tried 12 teas and coffees for free (and paid 50000 tp try the Luwak coffee) and shopped for teas and coffees to take home to family in their shop :)

Great Experience. A must do tour!! Free samples of Balinese traditional coffees, teas, various flavored coffees and teas.. Homegrown traditional tobacco to sample for cigarette smokers. Free testers for home brew spirits. Something for everyone. You can also buy them in their shop for you to take back to your country..

Great place to learn more about coffee and tea. The staff is very nice and informative, they explain everything ! At the end of the track you will have the chance to taste various teas and coffees for free ( and buy the one you loved after).Even if you are not a coffee or tea addict you will appreciate this activity.

Interesting and fun experience. Stopped here for a free tour of the coffee plantation. Saw cute sleeping civets and fresh fruits and herbs growing. They gave us a lovely sampler tray of all of their coffees and herbal teas, and you can pay 50000 IDR for a cup of Kopi Luwak. This was definitely worth trying and after having learned how it was made, I wasn't afraid to try the cat poo coffee. It was delicious. They have a shop where you can buy all of the coffees and teas that you have tried afterwards, as well as many other products, like incense, organic coconut oil, lip balms, creams, spices, etc. I think they make a killing off of the tourists that come through here. We bought a lot of great souvenirs to bring back, though I'm not sure that these are the best possible prices since its such a tourist spot. The herbal teas are so fantastic though, I wish I bought more! We learned a lot and even got to help roast the coffee beans and grind them up for Luwak coffee

Interesting place to visit. A must see, the view you get when hyou sit to try their products.
You can try for free all their teas and coffees (except the luwak coffee which costs like 4$ the cup) and to be honest I did no like it.
THe balinese coffee was very very good and not too much expensive.

Very interesting and educational. Our driver stopped here on the way to Ubud and we had no idea what to expect. We were pleasantly surprised at how interesting and educational the tour was. We had our own guide and she showed us through the gardens, past the animals and the coffee-making process. After that we sat down and had a chance to sample the different coffee and tea varieties. Finally we went to the gift shop where we could purchase, coffee, tea, souvenirs or a range of other things. There wasn't any pressure to buy.
Tea and coffee samplings...yum!. Wonderful experience...had a great time sampling the different Bali teas and coffees! I had purchased some items to bring home to family and friends!

Great little place. We stopped off here on our way to a tour of the rice paddies. We were shown the many different fruit and veg they had growing there. We were shown the processing methods and then we were shown to a table where we were give glasses of approx 15 different types of coffee and tea (for free). I thought this was brilliant and all it them were really tasty. The views from the seating area were fantastic. We were offered to try a cup of the Luwak coffee for 50k (this is very expensive for a coffee but it's not every day you get to try something like that). Then we were taken to the gift shop which we seed a bit pricey but had all the coffee previously tried as well as various spices produced at the plantation. Overall I would definitely advise people to visit here, especially coffee lovers.

Awareness about a´coffee. I learned a lot in this place and also about being grateful. I truly did not know about the whole process of making coffee and how much work was behind. I got to taste and even buy with me the amazing Luwak coffee. And I also got to taste so many different kind of coffee´s and tea. It was very educational and Im glad that I got the experience.

Very educational . We learnt a lot of how they make their coffee, she showed us and took us through the whole process. You then get to sit down and taste all the different coffees and teas that they have and you can purchase them to take home. I loved it!

Traditional Indonesian Coffee. all the hotels i stayed at in Bali served this great Indonesian coffee. I thought the Bali coffee that i bought here would be the same, sadly it was not. Also bought a couple of different varieties in the herbal tea...however for some reason they very very sweet. I definitely bought the NO SUGAR variety. Would dread to imagine how sweet the sugar version is.....So im a little disappointed as i bought 3-4 different varieties....and i haven't been thrilled with the flavour.
Luwak coffee , now Iv'e had the best .. Very enlightening . Tried Luwak coffee and many other products , produced there .A very comfortable facility .

Yeah it's a touristic trap. At the entrance we really didnt know how much the tour will cost and nobody was able to answer us. The tour was very quick, the guide showed us cinnamon, coffee lemon grass and other at least for european interesting plants. Then we had a degustation, about 13 different teas and coffee for free, we liked it very much. The only coffee, typical one costed 50,000 rupias.
