I didnt like it so much, so it is according to me worthless. At the end of the tour we were invited to the shop, where everything was soo much expensive, unless for me. So I dont recommend to buy there anything.

Tourist trap. TYpical tourist stop off for day trippers (I'm sure the drivers get commission for stopping there). YOu do get free coffee tasters with the hint to buy a special coffee which is hard to say no to. Great view of the valley from the cafe.

Great Coffee. Amazing View. We visited the Plantation as part of a day trip to Ubud. What an amazing place. The coffee tastings were great & the view over the rice paddies was amazing. Staff & service were excellent & all for free. Can highly recommend.
Coffee lovers. This is a must for all you coffee drinkers. Take your time indulge with all the different flavours. It's really worth experiencing the different flavours

Awesome place in Ubud! . Our guide Cok suggested this place as we were coming from visiting some temples. It was very interesting and interactive. I loved the tasting at the end which of course lead us to but quite a bit! The lemon grass tea and coconut coffee were two of my favorites.

Coffee plantation tranquility. Loved this little tour through the plantation. Learned a lot of the history of Balinese coffee and how they kept the lawack coffee beans hidden from the dutchies. Great sampling and could buy our favourites

Interesting but also expensive. This place was somewhat interesting and informative, they showed the different plants and the luwak.
But the guide sounded like she was bored and the prices were expensive.

Amazing tasting coffee! . Our driver from Legian to Ubud asked if we wanted to stop here on our way. Not a coffee drinker myself and thinking I just wanted to get to Ubud we stopped anyway as I'm in Bali so why not and my wife loves coffee and tea? Oh. My. God! This coffee and tea was very good. They make it all there but what is different is that it's all powder. They make the coffee into powder and add spices and other flavors. Most have 3-4 ingredients and you can get them without sugar added or honey added. You try about 15 different coffee and teas and pretty much all taste great! Enjoy the setting, enjoy the coffee and support and local business. The teas are also amazing. Powder as well but strong. Not like tea bags in the USA. They also have lewuk coffee which is ok. Weird drinking it knowing what it comes from. Not a huge operation and very peaceful. No pressure to buy the coffee but it tastes so damn good we had too. Our taster spoke very good English and had a great story about what he wants to do in life. Sorta sad to listen to it but he was very optimistic about his future. Listen, talk, enjoy coffee and relax in this beautiful setting!

An interesting experience - Poo coffee being the highlight.. Well this was a great "little" stop on our day tour that we had privately and personally planned.The stop was suggested by our driver so we thought, why not.We were warmly welcome to the cafe/store/demonstration/animal enclosure and seated to be given a taste of 8 or so varieties of coffee and tea. What was to be a quick visit was soon becoming a long one....at our choice.They went through the process of picking to roasting and preparing the beans for a final product. Explained the process of the "poo" coffee and how that comes about.Each and every tea and coffee we tried was amazing...and yes...we LOVED the poo coffee.There is a store there where everything you tried is available yet no one was pushy for you to make a purchase.We did enjoy a couple of extra cups of coffee while we were there though which is brewed right at the table while the beans are being roasted behind you.

A Brief Trip to Ubud - Bali. If you like coffee or tea it is well worth a visit to this small plantation, with an opportunity to see some coffee being roasted and a chance to taste various blends of coffee and different teas. Bet you won't come away without buying some!

A Coffee Experience .... The Kopi Kuwak or Civet Coffee is probably over-priced and i personally don't believe it all comes from the wild as i gotten to know it is mass produced with the civet bred on farms ... so unless $$$ is in excess this can be a ruthless buy which is heavily promoted even at the farms for a princely price of IDR50000/- per cup.

I Don't like Coffee But I Loved This. Really special tour of how coffee is made from plant-to cup. I loved the young man who took us for our tour. We decided to drink the lemur coffee and it was pleasantly nice. I enjoyed all the other tasters too.

Coffee and tea extravaganza. This was an experience I will never forget. Did not realise there were so many types of coffee and teas. We tasted them all, watched how they are made and the staff member was ever so helpful in her tour. We bought lots of teas and coffees to bring home and am enjoying them

Nice tea.... Not amazing for animal lovers. So to be fair firstly the tea and coffee tasting was lovely. When you arrive you are greeted by a staff member, he then shows you the type of coffee trees in a small sample garden area. This is charming but not the actual plantation. You are then shown the beans in a few states of processing. Then the sad part happens when you are offered to hold a bat which clearly doesn't like being out during day, never mind the rabies situation in Bali and the risk to you health. After which you are shown a hedgehog and four darling little animals in cages. After this you head to a table to sample tea and coffee all of which are lovely. You then are encouraged to purchase tea and coffee to take home for about $15aud a bag which we did as we felt we had to as there was no charge for the other elements. Honestly I wouldn't come back due to the animals being shown however the coffee and tea is nice so maybe if you are a bit less sensitive then it would be okay.
The luwak coffee is a must-taste!. Situated in the most picturesque valley, you can try a whole variety of coffees including luwak which comes from coffee beans partly digested by civit-like animals
Excellent for coffee lovers. If you love coffee this is a must do.I found this very interesting and the coffee and tea amazing.I have done this tour every time I go to Bali.

Yummy coffee and teas. Excellent place to try different Indonesian coffee and teas as well as the famous Luwak coffee. We enjoyed this place. No pressure to purchase and set price so no need to haggle - but we did manage to get a discount as we loved the coffee so much and bought quite a bit inn the end
Nice coffee place. Knowledgeable staffs who speaks rather decent English. Love the Ginseng coffee and Mangosteen Peel Tea which is really easy to go down on the throat.

A definite stop on your way back from Kintamani. Our taxi driver suggested this plantation on our way back from Kintamani. To be honest I wasn't really up for it - but when we stopped and got out I knew it wasn't what I thought at all.You are led through the plantation by a guide that tells you all about the coffee beans as well as the cocoa they grow too. Everything is done by hand - it takes 45mins to roast the coffee beans over a fire (which was damn hot for the lady sitting there doing it) and about 2 hours to do a kilogram of beans (I hope I have remembered that correctly).Everything is very well orchestrated - and it doesn't have to be a long stop either - we were in and out within an hour I would say. After you go through the plantation and hear about the process and of course the Luwak and the "poo" coffee (*giggle* from my 5 year old daughter)...you get to do a full taste test of all the teas and coffees they produce. We loved just about all of them - we bought the Vanilla coffee, Coconut coffee, Mango tea, Rice (yes Rice) tea and Lemongrass tea. And of course...had to get the 100% cocoa powder for hot chocolate for my daughter.It was well worth the trip and I would say definitely make this as a stop on your way to or from Kintamani. And its not tedious for kiddies either - short enough to manage!A big thank you to the team at Satri - we are still drinking your coffee here at home and enjoying it...thinking of you!

great farm!. My husband and i really enjoyed stopping by Satri Coffee plantation. OUr guide was so nice! totally forget his name. very interesting to see how their plantation works and more importantly really like supporting these people in their farming and staying close to nature. if you arent into farming or crops or that sort of thing- then skip but if you are! stop by - we really enjoyed it , learned a lot and got some great coffee and vanilla beans!
Luwak Coffe Stop. Friendly staff offering free samples of their Tea and Coffee. we bought some from the shop. Its an ok stop on the way back from the local temples.

Poor luwak . The experience was great with a little tour around the plantation and 12 tasters of different drinks, and it was all free! But it was sad seeing the luwak (a cat-like animal) locked up in a tiny cage.

Great experience, don't miss on your trip.. I wasn't a coffee drinker until stopping by here. When the driver suggested it, I went for the view of the plantation. The staff were welcoming, great service. Views beautiful & great introduction to the plantation, the process & tasting opportunities. I fell in love with coffee here & haven't stopped. A rich smooth flavour, in all it's varieties & don't miss the tea! Great experience. Worth stopping in for.
Great coffee. If you like coffee and tea this is a must. Great tasting session at the end and great coffee. Reasonable prices.
Choice of coffee.. Very nice coffee plantation with a guide to show you around and explain things to you. Lots of coffee samples to try and buy if you want to.
great. Got to see how they make coffee also tasted the most expensive coffee in the world and see animal who eats coffee bean.great place to go.
Soo beautiful 😍. Great time at the plantation. So beuatiful. Great coffe and our guide was sweet. Try the lemongrass the and the vanilla coffe. It's so good.
Yum. Had a great time, had a small tour and then stopped for some tastings which were all so delicious! Bought some coffee to take home unfortunately it was expensive so only got a small bag
Great experience!. A great experience and an amazing opportunity to sew how, not only the kopi luwak, but different spices i cultivated. And it's free!

À must see and do!. The coffee plantation is locaties in a beatifull landschapje. USB an experienced guide As you will walk through all kind of spices, fruit trees and of course coffee and cacao trees. You dan see the luwak cast who are there only to show. Coffee tasting is free and enjoyable. Even for kids who love the ginseng coffee. The luwak coffee you have to pay but who not. The shop is expensive. IT is your own choice. We loved thuis visit. Friendly people!

Wonderful coffee/tea tasting & informational tour!. We stopped here on the way back from the Titra Empul temple and were treated to a very informative tour of the grounds including seeing all of the natural fruits & spices growing in their natural habitat. We also saw the Lewaks sleeping in their cages (as they are nocturnal) before tasting the famous Lewak Coffee. First we were treated to a tasting of 12 cups - 7 coffees and 7 teas, all flavoured naturally by the fruits we saw earlier (ginger, apple, lemongrass, etc.). The guide was so nice & friendly that by the end we were taking pictures together and even added her as a friend on Facebook! We also bough some souvenirs to take home (coffee & teas). A great stop for any coffee/tea lover!

Great place to call in for a cuppa. Small, neat tidy place set up for tourists. Once seeing the plants and 1 caged animal, you are treated to some sample coffees. You must pay the $5 to have the Luwak coffee otherwise no point going there. You then can choose to buy the overpriced coffees on way out. Will only take about 30 mins.

Amazing coffee and tea tasting. . We had a guide to show us around the plantation, and point out what plants where what and different types of fruit. There are displays of a variety of coffee, vanilla, cinnamon etc to feel and smell. You can also see them roasting the beans and grinding them and have a go yourself. A guide will then take you up to a benched area where you can taste a variety of tea and coffee grown on the plot. This is amazing and they all taste very good especially the coconut coffee and lemongrass tea. The only thing we didn't like about this place was the caged civets, the enclosures are far too small and just not very pleasant. But overall the experience was good.

Informational and tasty!. There's a great, informational tour at the beginning and a free coffee/tea tasting at the end. All the coffees and teas are delicious. They also have really cheap lewak coffee and all of the lewak animals roam wild, instead of being caged like other planations. The gift shop has tons of great coffee, tea, incense, and fragrances (locally sourced) too. A must for any coffee or tea lover!

A place for coffee. The place was full of coffee trees, and some fruit and herb tree. We walked through a stony path, looking at many ripe and unripe beans bearing from trees. At the middle, they taught us how to grind and roast coffee in the traditional way. What I disliked was the lack of exhibit to experience
Not exciting. Probably could have done without wasn't informative and coffee is not good not worth the $5 per cup but hey you gotta do it!

Delicious. Going to this plantation was crazy to see! The guides were knowledgeable and would stop and give you details at every station. Trying the teas and coffees are not like having traditional westernized coffees. They have a thick sludge on the bottom, but don't let it ruin your experience! The "Poo" coffee was great, I plan on getting some shipped over since we finished ours within a week.

I love my coffee. By accident I was brought there by a guy in the street. I guess he gets commision or he has to do with my tip. I love my coffee, so it' s not the first plantation I visit. I am not sure if the coffee is still being processed the way they explain it. And the coffee is really expensive. But still, everything that has to do with coffee is ok with me. The coffee, tea and cocoa tasting is fun I do wish they wouldn't add palm sugar and so forth to the coffee. Strong and black that's the way!
Coffee please. Very well organised, informative and a fantastic range of teas and coffees to enjoy. The best part of course is the Luwak coffee which can be purchased.
Highlight of Ubud. I really enjoy the coffee plantation! So amazing and good! The shop at the end of the tour is very expensive unfortunately ! You must try the Luwak coffee

Glad we stopped. I had no expectations about the Satri Coffee Plantation but as a coffee lover I was intrigued. The welcome was warm and information plentiful about how the coffee produced. The tastings amongst the picturesque back drop was well worth the time. Loved it and left with quite a bit of coffee, tea and natural skin products. You won't be disappointed.

Awesome. Learnt so much they have such a different variety of plants in there plantation from coffee to cocoa vanilla beans mandarins they call orange beautiful drinks to try bought some home will return next visit

Amazing tasting. To tell you the truth, I really didn't feel like going to a Coffee Plantation...been there, done that elsewhere.But I truly enjoyed every minute of it! The Tea tasting platter was amazing.It was so well explained, by a sweet host, smiling, patient...every time I liked something, he would be so happy for me! Everyone who works there is super king and ... It was delish!! Full descriptions of the medicinal virtues and subtleties...wow!!!Then when the host told me I could go to the boutique to but these products, well...I could bring these delicious tea, coffee and honey back home with me.As a matter of fact I had some Balinese honey last night at home, and like magic, I was brought right back to the most beautiful island I've ever visited!!!!
good. loved the mangosteen tea and herbal lemon as well as there orange chocolate interesting story about the coffee
Its more sale shop. They dont explain enough about the coffee as they just offer you to try the taste and try their best to make you buy some expensive coffee..

Surprised. Wasn't too sure about stopping here but really gold we did. On arrival given a brief tour of the garden with an overview of each fruit tree as well as coffee and chocolate. We then sat down for free coffee and tea tasting including locally made chocolate in lovely surroundings over looking paddy fields. Very friendly staff and entrance to the plantation if free also. That said we spend about $40 on tea to bring back home!

Capoochino with a difference!. Very informative and interesting. Originally I wasn't overly fussed about stopping here but was really glad we did. Sampled many herbal teas and organic coffees. Opportunity to purchase products if you wished, but certainly no pressure by Putu, our guide, to do so.

Try the best and most expensive coffee in the world!. An English speaking guide took us around the plantation and showed us coffee, cinnamon, vanilla, cocoa, ginseng and ginger growing. We also saw the luwaks sleeping (they are nocturnal). We could also see the entire process of coffee production taking place - beans, roasting, grinding, and sifting, all done by hand in the traditional manner. Then we could sample many different flavored teas and coffees - this tour is not just for coffee lovers. The tour was free, but if you want to try luwak coffee you have to pay a small amount. The luwak coffee was indeed the best coffee I've ever tasted, so don't miss it! Also take some money to buy coffee or tea on the shop. You'll definitely want to after you try the samples! We only spent about an hour at the plantation, yet this tour was one of my best Bali experiences!

Wow!. This place was a short visit for some quick local knowledge on the makings of Lewak coffee. Our tour guide was very passionate and we enjoyed our time with her. This is a great attraction to visit after the rice terraces and perhaps on the way to the volcano as it doesn't take much time but is definitely something worth doing.

Had to try the Luwak Coffee. This was a really fun attraction. The tour of the plantation and tasting of various teas and coffees is free, but the Luwak coffee tasting is 50,000 rupiahs (about $5 CDN) per cup. It was definitely worth sharing a cup of it to say you've have coffee made from beans in weasel poop! On your way into the plantation, there are many plants growing from pineapples to ginger and sugar cane. Take your time strolling in to check them out. You can see and feed the animals while you walk in. A guide will great you and show you how they make the coffee. They'll provide you a tray of coffees and teas to try out and escort you through the gift shop when you are done your tasting. It was a great learning experience and would suggest to anyone that this is a "must do"!

Try the luwak coffee. Worth a visit to say you've tried luwak coffee when you get home. It's the only place you'll be able to afford a cup of it to be honest. Lovely but a little cruel the way the civit cats are kept wired on coffee in cages.
Luwak Coffee. This was a nice little diversion on the way to the volcano one day. We were able to sample various teas and coffees produced by this family coffee plantation.
Interesting. Didn't know much about coffee until you visit a coffee plantation. Truly a unique experience. And they offer tastings for free whilst you sit down to a beautiful view!

Great tasting coffee and teas!. We arrived expecting more of a "plantation" feel but it's more like a beautiful lush tropical garden on the edge of the jungle. The Luwak's definitely prefer to eat coffee beans! There's no pressure to buy anything after the free tasting (there's about 5 coffees to try and maybe 8 'tea' varieties) although you do have to pay to taste the Luwak coffee. We did spend quite a lot of money in the gift shop here (for Bali standards!) but we absolutely loved so many of the coffees and teas that we just had to take some of each home! We did get them all through Australian customs!

Excellent Coffee - worth a visit. As this was our second trip to Bali, I needed to try real Luwak Coffee. The Satri plantation was beautiful, clean, and didn't feel like a gimmick for tourists. I had a chance to look at the coffee making process as well as sample all different types of Balinese coffee. And yes, I did drink a cup of the Luwak coffee (was good!) and bought quite a few packages to take home to family and friends. The staff were very friendly and accommodating. We never felt rushed or pressured to buy anything.The only negative from the whole visit was being ambushed in the parking by street peddlers after the visit to the plantation. I can't fault Satri for this, but my advice is when you visit, get back into your transportation quickly after leaving the plantation to avoid the trinket salesmen :-)

Nice experience. Coffee very expensive.. We visited a coffe plantation with our driver- it's really fun and a good experience, especially if you like coffee. You get to try the different coffees and of course the luwak coffee- after the tasting you go to the shop. We had to find out the that we paid almost double the price compared to any other place in town.

Luwak Coffee. We visited this area on recommendation of our driver/tour person. Convinced they must get commission. Sampled different teas/coffees complimentary and purchased Luwak Coffee IDR 50,000 for a cup and IDR 2250000, 50gr to take home for later, was told it would be more expensive else where. We found it at the airport cheaper!

Excellent information and demonstrations. A great setting in the mountains where you walk along a path and are shown all the different coffee, cocoa and fruit plants/trees. Then a guide will show you the process of transforming the coffee beans from the tree into something you can drink - you can even have a go at roasting beans too!. Further down the path and to a shelter you taste all 12 varieties of coffee and tea they produce fro FREE - including the famous and rare Luwak coffee (which cost us $100,000Rp). Then into the shop to purchase which ones we liked. We were not pushed or hurried through and felt very welcome. A great place to relax after a day driving to the Volcano.

Try Luwak coffee. Luwak coffee or the poop coffee is tagged at its high price for a reason. One of the strongest coffees I have ever tasted. The host gives a nice tour of the region with no pressure to buy anything. There are 9 complimentary coffees served against the backdrop of steep green coffee plantations. That experience itself is enough to make the trip worthwhile.

Luwak coffee is a must. Great guides who show and explain how all the different coffees and teas are made. They also give you about 10 different teas and 10 different coffees to try including the famous luwak coffee. Well worth the visit

So interesting!. I love bringing groups here, Tim, the owner makes it so interesting. There is a half hour talk all about producing coffee with a demonstration, finishing with coffee and chocolate cake on the lawn. They also have splendid souvenir shop with goodies that you will not find anywhere else. Just go, and at the same time, help Tim raise money for the "Save the Rhino" fund.

Coffee, Chocholate, Vanilla, Cinnamon,& Tropical Fruits!. If you are staying around Ubud and you are tired of visiting so many different big temples and want to see something different, you must visit this coffee plantation field! There are Coffee, Chocholate, Vanilla, Cinnamon,& Tropical Fruits in the field! They prepare their special coffee in front of you as well! You can taste all 12 drinks for free and order one of them you love most (this is ethically obligatory) ! Plus, if you want, you can buy more from shop but prices were expensive for me. You dont have to purchase at all.

Do try Kopi Luwak. Kopi Luwak (Luwak coffee) is one of the weirdest and costliest coffee around the world. But its a must try!. i also loved other variations of the teas and coffee specially the lemongrass tea is simply amazing!

Wasn't very impressed unfortuantly. The guide spent about 2 minutes explaining the process and it was very hard to actually see any of the plantation as they hurried you through a prepared walkway. As soon as the coffee tasting was over you were hurried into the shop and hoovered over by your guide until you were made to feel guilty enough to purchase the over priced goods.

you get to taste amazing tea, coffee and chocolates!. has nice stuff to offer. You can take back a lot of material from here. If you do buy the wine from there, the packaging is pretty bad. You might need to store the wine in better plastic bottles with tighter caps if you want to carry it back in your Check in baggage. Ours emptied enroute in the bag itself.

Not bad for an hour's stop off. Our driver took my husband and I here on the way to Ubud after we'd asked for some sightseeing en route. Having visited similar plantations in India, this was on a smaller scale but still nice and shady. Our guide was a young cheeky chappy so we had a laugh as well as learning about the plants and comparing uk / bali usage of ingredients. Unfortunately the mongoose are held in very small cages with bars on the floor so I would like to suggest that improvements are made to the housing of these animals please!We were seated in a shady area at the end of the tour and brought out a big selection of teas and coffees to try. The 'special' mongoose poo coffee is not included - this is charged at 50K rupiah per glass if you want to try (we did just for the fun but it's not very nice!). All the drinks have a lot of sugar in so taste quite nice, but we really liked the mangosteen tea, coconut tea and spiced chocolate drinks so decided to buy these in their shop at the end. They also sell spices and other bits. The prices are not cheap but I had no issue with buying the ones we wanted (and they accept credit card). Beware - they have a snake in a box by the shop where they try to get you to hold it for a picture (I imagine for a fee). My husband hates snakes so we made it very clear to our guide who told the photo lady no for us.

More relaxed and informative than most coffee plantations.. We've been to coffee plantations before, where they run you through the trees, give you samples and then push you into the gift shop...but not here! We had a lovely guided walk in the plantation. Our guide took the time to show us species of tropical plants including coffee. The products are all organic and they only produce and sell in their own shop, so they can sell out of some of the popular products toward the end of the day. She answered all our questions and visited with us while we sampled coffees and teas. She was friendly and informative and we felt most relaxed. We suggest you get here earlier- we arrived at 9:30 and by 10:45 when we were leaving, the parking lot was full. Tour and tasting are free (except Luwak coffee-$50,000 rupiah same as other plantations), products in the store are comparably priced to other outlets.

Great coffe and tea. We drove into this parking area and walked down a gravelly path and we were shown some jack fruit snd some coffe trees and then we walked down further to where some young girls and some women were roasting some coffee beans. This lovely young lady who spoke excellent english came over to us and explained exactly what they were doing and showed us the difference between a male and female coffee bean and explained how the male coffee bean has more intense flavour. We were then given a tasting similar to a wine tasting but with several different coffees and several different teas. I loved the mangisteen tea and my wife loved the rosella tea. We the were given some lowak coffee which is very expensive as it is made from the poo of the sivet. The sivet is a small cat like nocturnal animal who eats the coffee ripened coffee beans then passes the beans still intact in its faeces. Its poo is collected and cleansed and treated till it is safe and the made into loeak coffee. Well worth the experience great time.

Please go here! . Authentic coffee and tea and cocoa plantation - first a little tour of the produce grown and explanation of the processes, then a free taster of 10 coffees and teas - coconut, vanilla, ginseng coffees, ginger, lemongrass teas, and then even option to try 5 more flavours for free! Luwak coffee is obviously a Balinese delicacy and any visitor should try it - 50000 IDR (£2.50) for a cup. Beautiful views of the huge plantation. Great shop - we bought lots of professionally packaged authentic Balinese coffee and chocolates for ourselves and as gifts to take home. The man who took us around was so lovely. Please tip him something when you go, he looked so shocked when we gave him a little something for his help. It isn't a long trip - maximum 45 mins to 1 hour. It is complexity free unless you want to try the luwak coffee.

Good experience!. Fun learning about indonesian coffee plantation and growing techniques. Also it is very interesting to learn about the kopi luwak a unique technique of making coffee in this country. Good one time experience.

The Coffee is Great Especially the Lewark!. This is a must if you would like to learn the history of coffee making in Bali. All the different coffee plants are shown with your guide explaining in full detail. You can sample the coffees for free but the Lewark coffee is IDR50,000 but well worth the cup thereof! This is the very expensive coffee processed from the coffee beans eaten by the Lewark which you can also see, very cute little mammals. Yes, you drink coffee from the poo of the Lewark! Just try it, when you understand you will really appreciate!! The taste is unique and exquisite!!

Place is nice but . Me and my husband had nice coffee to taste they gave us deferent kind of coffee and we decided to buy more then we find at home they cheated us the coffee u Taste it's not the same u buy the just gave us like brown powder and doesn't related to coffee at all by all means so just avoid to buy any thing from them

facanating experiece. we arrived and were greeted by a lovely young man with great English,he walked us through the garden explain the different plants they harvested and allowing us to touch and smell the leaves.We then seen the mongoose who eat the berries that the coffee comes from .This got the kids attention and they were also able to have a turn at hand grinding the beans.We sat down to a free coffee & tea tasting session and we asked if which one we like the best.The tea and coffee was lovely and the kids loving tasting the tea too.The plantation is set in a beautiful area and we were able to get a few good pics.Only let down for me was we were told that the plantation was the only place to buy the coffee or tea in Bali,so we stocked up but when arrived at the air port was selling it for a third of the price.Ir is a wonderful tour and well worth popping in for a cuppa

Beautiful. The plantation was beautiful. I was a little hesitant when our guide took us there thinking it was kind of a tourist trap. It kind of was but I didn't mind since the plantation was so incredibly gorgeous. We strolled through it on a rainy day and our guide pointed out all the different fruit/flower trees. It was kind of magical. I even enjoyed the tea/coffee tasting which of course leads to spending money..didn't mind spending money here though. Totally worth it.
Great coffee.. Beautiful views, fabulous coffe and an interesting place to visit. A plesant place to be on a warm Bali day. Lots of interesting things to learn about coffee.

Worth a look if you're going past. My wife and I enjoyed having a guided tour of the 'plantation', with the guide explaining the different plants and how the coffee is made, including that which is made from the droppings of Lewaks (similar perhaps to a possum). At the end of a short tour you are given a number of different coffees and teas to try, then the option to purchase any of them. The coffeees are reasonably expensive but you don't have to buy anything if you don't want to. The whole thing probably took an hour - we went there as part of a day tour around Ubud and surrounds.

Must visit for coffee lovers. I am a coffee lover and hardly leave a chance to try out new coffees. Freshly brewed and local cultivation is an added advantage. You can taste and then buy whatever you like. Price is something you need to be careful about though.
taste authentic coffee. To actually be in the coffee plantation and see the lush trees and then try the very good brew afterwards. It is such a great experience.

luwak coffee. Please do not drink or buy this coffee as the civet cats are kept in appalling environments purely for the novelty for tourists in drinking this coffee. They are kept invery small cages, some with wire mesh floor so nowhere to walk/stand. I was told they are released after 5 years!!
Lovely way to spend an afternoon. When in Bali moments. Has an excellent store to pick up locally grown coffee, teas and various spices. The process is very interesting.
Coffww. While this place is slightly interesting it is a rip off the purpose is to sell over priced tea and coffee.
Great insight. Wonderful area, interesting information and "hands on experiences" not too far from Ubud. Worth a visit.

take it or leave it. A quick walkthrough the garden before sitting down to try the various samples which are all fantastic - unfortunately what you buy to take with you is a pale imitation. If you feel guilt tripped into buying something by your pleasant guide just get something small - the prices are frankly insane!

Great Coffe. Coffee plantation tour is a nice addition to your Ubud tour. The place is nice, you are given information about various coffee and trees. Then they give you various coffees to taste for free. The view from this place in pleasant. At the end, you may choose to buy coffee of your choice.
Very small attraction. Worth going if your passing through but not a lot to see , but of a let down really as I'm quite the coffee fiend .

Well run and great experience . We visited the Sitria Coffee plantation after a trek to Mt Batur . They have it well set up and give you a thorough and factual experience. You are shown coffee plants, different beans and have a practical demonstration of the preparation of the coffee and spices used in the making process. You are also introduced to the Lewak, a coffee bean eating cat/possum. The coffee beans that are not digested in the Lewak are collected and processed to produce a curiosity. One that I satisfied by tasting Lewak coffee and I can report that I found it a very smooth drink. The plantation also does a nice tasting and if you find one you like then you can buy some in the gift shop. The staff are very pleasant and make the experience worthwhile. There is also a good selection of teas available.

Kind of a tourist trap.... It's a coffee farm, that is basically there for tourists. It is a stop on most tours through Bali regardless of what else you are seeing.Pros: it's relatively quick. The lewacks are cute, but sleep during day. Cons: tourist trap!, they are there to try to sell you coffee and junk merchandise only. Buyer beware the super expensive lewak coffee is simply not good, brought some home and expertly brewed it...the cheaper bali coffee is better but even that is overpriced. Conclusion: avoid if possible, but if you take a tour (which you should also avoid) you will inevitably stop here, but you can at least breeze through quickly!

Remember The Bucket List??. Who can forget that wonderful scene in the hospital room when Morgan Freeman so gently debunks Jack Nicholson's elitist coffee bean and service gear? Well here it is - the genuine kopi luwak (sp?) coffee bean and the animals that 'produce' it. Here it's dubbed 'cappoochino'! And, yes, it must be the most expensive coffee in the world and, frankly, we didn't think it was worth it. You get to sample (for free) about 12 different coffees and teas (a couple of which were outstanding) but you have to pay for the poo bean coffee. This plantation is worth a stop for sure. It's free, the attendants are sweet and friendly and I even got to stir some beans that were being roasted.

A variety of coffee for tasting. The place is ok has Luwak coffee. I am not sure if I would want to drink that since it is made after feeding a coffee seed to Luwak and subsequently processed from its excreta. The shop inside had a wide variety of tea/coffee powder.

Fun stop. My husband and I and three year old daughter went to the coffee plantation, we had a private guide who showed us all the different plants growing on the farm before handing us off to the staff who explained the coffee process to us! It was great to know I'm not the only one with grounds in my coffee - the Balinese don't use coffee filters! We enjoyed the samples, even my daughter loved the teas and took a small sip of the coffees. We bought some treasures to take home for family too

Awesome coffee. Enjoyed a great range of teas - the lemongrass is fab - and coffees at this lovely plantation. But it's the Luwak coffee which is the star. It is pricey but tastes so good. The staff explain how it's made so it's no wonder it's expensive. Well worth the visit.

Not the real thing. Kopi lewak is "the most expensive coffee in the world" because the civets supposedly select only the choicest of beans. If you lock them in cages and feed them any beans, it defeats the purpose! Now you just have poo coffee, and really sad-looking cute animals :-(
coffee tea anyone. interesting place - sampled lots of great tea and coffees but of course the "cat coffee" was a treat- great story go and research it.

Kopi Luwak. The most expensive coffe on the world, made from the excrements of small lovely animals. Indosnesians call them Luwak. You will see how this coffe is made and you can taste some other tea and coffe from the producer. Very interesting and nice nature.

Lewak coffee making. This is a great tourist attraction of Lewak coffee production. We were met by a guide who explained the plants and fruit trees as we walked down to the Lewak animal cages. I've never seen a giant passionfruit before, it was the size of a football ! The cages each had one animal per cage with fresh coffee beans for consumption. Then there was the pooped beans waiting for collection. We then saw the beans drying, roasting, grinding process etc. It was all very interesting. Finally we went to the sampling balcony where there are tables to sit at whilst waiting for free samples of teas and coffees. Each tray had a variety of seven samples. We did purchase a cup of the Luwak coffee and it is absolutely an acquired taste. This is a definite must do tour.

fabulous place. I visited here today whilst on a whistle stop tour with a driver. My driver pointed out which bushes were the Bali coffee and which weren't. There are lots of other fruits growing there which were nice to see in their natural environment. The girls there explained about how the coffee is processed and how the Lewak coffee is different. You get to try several different types of organic teas as well as different coffees for free, however you do need to pay to try the Lewak coffee. i was looking forward to trying it, but strangely enough it wasn't as nice as the normal Bali coffee. The ginger tea is to die for and so good for you.
Very enjoyable. Was really looking for the kopi luwak coffee, but strangely ended up enjoying the other teas more. Enjoyable and interesting, worth a visit

Amazing!!!. My partner and I loved this place!!!! It was such an amazing experience and one that we still talk about. The ride out there is beautiful from Ubud (I would suggest going on scooters if possible to experience it fully). The staff there are amazing, relaxed and are happy to sit and chat to you about their lives and villages etc. The teas and coffees are all free samples and you could sit there for hours looking over the forest drinking the amazing teas and coffees and never spend a cent. Once you are finished before you leave make sure you go through the shop and buy some of the teas to take home with you! We bought heaps and we are still drinking them! Wishing we bought more!

Coffee Time. Great time to reach to coffee plantation area and see the animal which eats the seeds of coffee and after 3 days it comes out after many enzymatic reactions. It's the most expensive coffee in the world- Luwaq. One cup is 50000 rupees equal to 4 dollars.Many other coffees you can try for free.Good introduction. Love it.
Luwak. Great walk seeing how they make Luwak and seeing all other produce (a blessed bali). And then trying different types of coffee and teas. Loved it

I drank poop coffee!. This is a must see! The samples o's tea and coffee were delicious. The view of the terraced rice fields was unique, but drinking coffee that is processed through a mercat was a new experience. This was fun!

Wrong information . The exact name for this place is Satria agrowisata, located in tampaksiring, not in ubud. Kindly correct this information, or perhaps merge it with the 'real' Satria agrowisata's TripAdvisor page as it confuses travellers like me.
Well worth a visit. Great selection of locally grown coffee and tea. Samples are provided of all products and available for purchase. Nice to visit something authentically Balinese.

The CatPooChino!. The Loumak is a little animal that eats the coffee beans and when it comes out the other end it is harvested and made into the most expensive coffee on the planet. But besides that you can taste all their coffees and see how herbs and fruit are grown. Very interesting....

Amazing coffee and herbal tea tasting!. loved walking through and learning about the different things grown here, from ginger, cinnamon, cocoa, to coffee, mangosteen, and rosella! Had our sampler in the most beautiful setting! Definitely worth a visit and would love to have taken home all the teas!

A must try - poop coffee. A unique experience and worth trying. A guide greets you and takes you on a quick tour (15-20 min) of the farm where they explain the process of how they make the poop coffee, show you all the various spices they also grow there which was very cool. You then grab a table along a mountain side with incredible views and they bring you 8 different coffees and teas to sample for free all made from the ingredients from the farm (ginseng tea, cocoa, vanilla coffee and more). If you want to try the poop coffee it was $5 CAD. You can walk down and out on to a wooden terrace for a further view and great picture opportunity. Once you're done your coffee samplers you walk through a store where you can buy some of what you tried if you like. They weren't pushy and didn't force you to make a purchase though. Neat experience to try if you have about an hour.

An absolute must - free!. You are guided through the plantation to view various coffee trees, cocoa trees & fruits.Our guide had excellent English & enlightened us on the journey of a coffee bean into our mug - it was GREAT!Then, we were prepared a sample of 8 coffee/teas - Bali coffee, Ginseng coffee, Coconut coffee, Mocha, Cocoa, Lemongrass tea, Saffron tea (with Tamarind & Tumric) and Ginger tea. My oh my YUMMY!!! Not to mention the breathtaking view!! Couldn't resist getting a few packets of coffee to bring home. The ginseng & coconut coffee was our favourite!
kopi luwak. that was probably spelt wrong sorry. I was loath to try the kopi luwak but it truly is amazing and when you see the process you realise that there is nothing 'yucky' about it at all.

Really interesting. This is well worth a visit .Firstly there is the walk through the gardens where there is every imaginable fruit and plant -bring a local guide to get a full explanation - by the way everybody in Ubud seems to know all local details! Then you see the traditional way of coffee making - still in use. Then to the sampling menu of coffees and teas for free unless you want to taste he 'special one'. Everything is explained in detail by the gentle hostess. I think I have kept several illnesses at bay as a result of the various teas I drank. Then off to the shop - but no pressure to buy anything- still it is hard to resist all those 'cures'.

Possum Poo Coffee A Must!. Great place. The staff guide you quickly through the process of making their unique Luwak Coffee (yep..those little possums eat the bean, poo the bean and that thar bean makes coffee!!) and you can have a go at roasting the beans and crushing them. You end up in their cafe which has the most beautiful views of the plantation where you are served a selection of all their coffees along with, if you wish to pay for it, a full cup of their signature Luwak coffee.By the way...it tasted amazing!

coffee & a view. i love plants & therefore i loved the coffee plantation tour. they have all sorts of exotic plants growing that you can photograph. this one had tasting tables with a view. ( there are many plantations in a row, so perhaps they all have a view )? you try out approx 12 types of coffee/teas. some are REALLY good. ( i wish i would have bought the lemon grass tea ), but i bought mangosteen & rosella ( which is different from rose! ) and i bought bali coffee. this plantation is organic. thats why i bought here as opposed to a cheaper market, because i know its organic. yes, its cheaper in the markets. at the end of the tastings they ask if you want to try the luwak coffee for 50,000IDR ( approx $4.50 USA ) . this is the Luwak animal poo coffee. i tried it because this is probably how the guy gets paid. and they probably get commission by what you buy in their shop. so if you like the guy, buy up.
